Combinator.analysis package

Submodules

Combinator.analysis.analysis_functions module

Combinator.analysis.analysis_functions.combine_tajectories(adata: AnnData, scores: list, combined_trajectory_name: str) → AnnData[source]

Given a list of previously calculated Combinator scores, users can use this function to align them and combine them for aid in downstream applications.

Parameters:

  • adata – standard scanpy compatible AnnData object that contains all single cell information after Combinator.run has be called on it

  • scores – a standard python list of the names of the Combinator score columns that are stored in adata.obs that you wish to align and combine

  • combined_trajectory_name – the column name within the adata.obs that will store the combined trajectory scores

Returns:

AnnData

Combinator.analysis.analysis_functions.monte_carlo_pvalue(adata: AnnData, cluster_column: str, combinator_column_name: str, combinator_signature: str, project_dir: str, mc_mode: str, analysis_dir: str, mc_permutations: int = 50, cpu_num: int = 5, essential_mode: bool = False, x_percent: float = 0.2)[source]

Run permutation analysis for specified Combinator columns to calculate p-values for each cell’s pseudotime ranking using the Monte Carlo method.

Parameters:

  • adata – standard scanpy compatible AnnData object that contains all single cell information after combinator.run has be called on it

  • combinator_column_name – is the column name within the adata.obs that the contain the scores calculated in a previous run of Combinator; can be the filtered or unfiltered scores

  • project_dir – string indicating full path to directory where the user’s project files are. The monte carlo method works by creating temporary file stores for each different permutation that then get removed as results are collected so as to avoid out of memory errors

  • mc_mode – string indicating which flavor of the algorithm to apply the monte carlo method on. Available choices are: ‘mat_wise’: the full dataset is shuffled such that each cell for gene has a random value from the original dataset ‘gene_sample’: for each of the signature genes under study, a normal distribution is calculated and positive values are randomly sampled for each cell for that signature. Combinator is then run on each version of the dataset for the specified number of permutations

Returns:

numpy array

Combinator.analysis.analysis_functions.simulate_trajectory(adata: AnnData, cluster_column: str, combinator_column_name: str, cell_cutoff: int = 50, smooth: float = 0.15, cells=None, cmap: str | LinearSegmentedColormap = 'magma', **kwargs)[source]

Simulate trajectories along a 100 point differentiation path.

Parameters:

  • adata – standard scanpy compatible AnnData object that contains all single cell information after Combinator.run has be called on it

  • cluster_column – string specifying the column name that contains the cell grouping information that users would like to use to simulate a trajectory through

  • combinator_column_name – the column name within the adata.obs that the contain the scores calculated in a previous run of Combinator that will be filtered

  • cell_cutoff – integer specifying the minimum number of cells that each cluster of specified metadata column must have with a Combinator score > 0

  • smooth – float used by csaps when creating spline through each cluster

  • cmap – matplotlib color palette or custom cmap for visualizing the trajectory on the heatmap

  • kwargs – additional arguments specific for seaborn and matplotlib

Returns:

a seaborn clustermap
